author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: How to Fall in Love With Lentils
description: I had my first lentil as an adult, and I want to say it was somewhere in France. (My mom, a terrific Japanese home cook, didn’t keep dried or canned lentils in the pantry; they didn’t figure much into her cooking, nor mine when I moved out.) I think those first lentils came to me in a simple salad, pebbly little de Puys dressed in a mustardy vinaigrette, maybe with some carrot or onion in there. I can’t remember the specifics, just the lentils: tender but not mushy, earthy but not too beany, and adorably small.
content: I had my first lentil as an adult, and I want to say it was somewhere in France. (My mom, a terrific Japanese home cook, didn’t keep dried or canned lentils in the pantry; they didn’t figure much into her cooking, nor mine when I moved out.) I think those first lentils came to me in a simple salad, pebbly little de Puys dressed in a mustardy vinaigrette, maybe with some carrot or onion in there. I can’t remember the specifics, just the lentils: tender but not mushy, earthy but not too beany, and adorably small.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: In British Columbia, a Political Party’s Collapse Echoes an Earlier Election
description: The end of a coalition of Conservatives and Liberals over 70 years ago led to a surprising election result and reshaped the province’s politics.
content: To anyone following politics recently in British Columbia, it sounds familiar: An alliance of Liberals and Conservatives collapses, and then a botched attempt to thwart the left wing ends up elevating a moribund party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 12, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 12, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about the halt in the George J. Mitchell scholarship program because of funding difficulties misspelled the surname of a former speaker of the House. He was Tip O’Neill, not O’Neil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Allan Blye, 87, Dies; ‘Smothers Brothers’ Writer and ‘Super Dave’ Creator
description: In his wide-ranging career, he also helped write Elvis Presley’s comeback special and appeared on an early version of “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood.”
content: Allan Blye, a television comedy writer and producer who helped cement the Smothers Brothers’ reputation for irreverence in the late 1960s and later collaborated with Bob Einstein to create the hapless daredevil character Super Dave Osborne, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: California Rejects Bid for More Frequent SpaceX Launches
description: A commission denied a request to increase the number of rocket launches on the state’s central coast, citing environmental concerns.
content: A California state commission this week rejected the U.S. Space Force’s bid to increase the number of SpaceX rocket launches on the state’s central coast, citing concerns about the environmental impacts of the launches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Israeli Strikes on Northern Gaza Kill at Least 20, Aid Workers Say
description: Israel’s military said it was “operating with great force” against Hamas and allied groups and issued new evacuation orders, as it also continued its campaign in Lebanon.
content: The humanitarian crisis in the northern Gaza Strip deepened on Saturday as an Israeli bombardment killed at least 20 people, trapped thousands more and prompted one of the area’s last functioning hospitals to issue desperate pleas for assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily C. Hughes
title: Scary Books for Scaredy-Cats
description: Looking to dip your toe into horror this Halloween season? Entry-level thrills by Shirley Jackson, Victor LaValle and T. Kingfisher are a good place to start.
content: Given the sheer volume of horror fiction published over the past decade, it can be hard for the sensitive yet curious reader to know where to start. Fear is heavily individual — what sends me screaming from the room might leave you unmoved — so it’s difficult to predict what will or won’t frighten, disturb or disgust any one person. But there are ways to dip a toe into the genre without scaring yourself silly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Blissful Stretch
description: Katie Hoody makes a New York Times Crossword debut with feeling.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Katie Hoody’s first crossword for The New York Times. I always love it when a constructor debuts with a Friday or Saturday themeless grid, even though I know that there’s not always a direct correlation between the difficulty of solving puzzles and making them. (I still picture one of those children who go to an Ivy League university at 10 and get on the local news.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Vows to Unleash More Borrowing to Spur Economy and Strengthen Banks
description: The finance minister said Beijing would sell bonds to supplement spending and help banks but did not detail how much.
content: China’s powerful Ministry of Finance said on Saturday that it would borrow more to help cash-short localities and put more money in the hands of state-owned banks, an effort to address a severe slowdown in real estate and shore up crumbling consumer confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Kent Nishimura
title: In This ‘Oval Office,’ Tourists Can ‘Solve or Start a World Crisis’
description: The White House Historical Association has opened a new museum that aims to provide insight into the difficult choices that presidents face.
content: For most of the last 75 years, it would have been impossible for a family touring Washington, D.C., to recreate the iconic photo of John F. Kennedy Jr. as a toddler, playing under the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office while his father directs the affairs of government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Jones
title: Love Lessons
description: The editor of the long-running Modern Love column reflects on two decades of working with people’s deeply personal stories.
content: The Modern Love column debuted 20 years ago this month — on Halloween, scarily enough — with a story by a lifelong bachelor, Steve Friedman, who was trying to feel OK about being dumped. He wrote: “She dumped me. What’s important are not the details but the pronoun placement, ‘she’ preceding ‘me.’ But there is no villain here. My therapist suggests I repeat this mantra to myself. So I do. There is no villain here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Suffs’ Won Tony Awards for Best Score and Book. Now It’s Closing.
description: The musical, created by Shaina Taub, announced that it will play its final performance on Jan. 5 and start a national tour next fall.
content: “Suffs,” a new musical about the American women’s suffrage movement, has a lot going for it: Its producers include Hillary Rodham Clinton and Malala Yousafzai, it won Tony Awards for its score and its book, and its audiences seemed energized by how the show’s themes resonated with the candidacy of Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Manual Dexterity
description: Gary Larson and Doug Peterson’s puzzle already comes with instructions, but just in case. …
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica M. Goldstein
title: A Twist on the Celebrity-Interview Podcast: Add Two Civilians
description: In a podcast landscape where famous people are always talking to each other, “Podcrushed” tweaks the formula and, for good measure, adds some adolescent angst.
content: In the lush, softly lit studio where nearly 60 years ago the Beach Boys recorded “Pet Sounds” and changed pop music forever, the hosts of the “Podcrushed” podcast are preparing to interview their latest guest: Chase Stokes, star of the Netflix teen-treasure-hunting drama “Outer Banks.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: A Nobel Honor To the Survivors Of Atom Bombs
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 12, 2024
content: “Please abolish nuclear weapons while we are alive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: A Conversation With JD Vance
description: The Republican vice-presidential candidate rejects the idea that he’s changed, defends his rhetoric and still won’t say if Trump lost in 2020.
content: From the moment JD Vance came onto the national stage, he was inextricably linked to Donald Trump. As the author of the best-selling book “Hillbilly Elegy,” Vance was initially the Trump whisperer, explaining the Trump phenomenon and 2016 win to shocked liberals. Back then, Vance didn’t like Trump. He called him an “idiot,” condemned what he saw as Trump’s dangerous rhetoric and wondered in a private message whether Trump could become “America’s Hitler.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 490
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
title: One of the Loneliest Countries Finds Companionship in Dogs
description: They have become pampered family members in South Korea, which has the world’s lowest birthrate and where much of the population lives alone.
content: The deceased lay wrapped in a cotton blanket, surrounded by white roses and hydrangea, angelic figurines and lit candles and incense. A wall-mounted screen displayed photographs of him. His 71-year-old companion, Kim Seon-ae, convulsed with tears as she bid farewell, caressing his head and face. Next door, young uniformed morticians prepared for his cremation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Ruth Igielnik
title: Trump Leads in Arizona as Harris Holds an Edge in Pennsylvania, New Polls Show
description: The latest Times/Inquirer/Siena polls found Donald Trump with a six-point advantage in Arizona, and Kamala Harris with a four-point lead in Pennsylvania.
content: Two of the nation’s most-contested battleground states — Pennsylvania and Arizona — illustrate the difficulties each campaign faces in gaining a clear advantage in the final stretch of the 2024 race, with Kamala Harris maintaining a narrow lead in Pennsylvania but Donald J. Trump continuing to hold an advantage in Arizona, according to a new pair of New York Times/Philadelphia Inquirer/Siena College polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Former U.S. Soldier Is Sentenced to 14 Years for Planning to Help ISIS
description: Pvt. Cole Bridges pleaded guilty last year to charges of attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization and attempting to murder U.S. military service members.
content: A former soldier in the U.S. Army was sentenced on Friday to 14 years in prison after pleading guilty to attempting to provide ISIS with information to help plan an ambush he thought would result in the deaths of U.S. soldiers in the Middle East, according to the U.S. Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Composting Bin Dos and Don’ts: Can Your Building Restrict Your Access?
description: Every building is different. What to do with internal trash and recycling storage are up to the residents and managers.
content: Q: The management company for my New York City co-op is restricting our access to the new composting bins, which the city provides, to one 24-hour period every week. These “brown bins” are part of the city’s mandatory composting program. The city says there are no special days or limited hours for composting, but the management company says it is limiting the collection time to minimize pests and odors. I have a galley kitchen and cannot keep a week’s worth of food waste. I can use the orange smart bins on the street, but it’s frustrating that the management company is disregarding the purpose of the program. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Marge Locker
title: A Heroine Determined to Live Alone, and to Get Pregnant
description: The protagonist of Eva Baltasar’s novel “Mammoth” contains multitudes, and that’s the way she likes it.
content: Eva Baltasar’s “Mammoth” is a book of contradictions even before it begins. Despite its title, it is seemingly a featherweight, not a giant, clocking in at hardly 100 pages. But this is a surprising slim novel that trembles with the force of an approaching stampede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jonathan Weisman
title: Trump Rally in Aurora, Colo., Is Marked by Nativist Attacks
description: The former president continued to make claims about the city that have been disputed by local officials, including its Republican mayor.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump escalated the nativist, anti-immigration rhetoric that has animated his political career with a speech Friday in Aurora, Colo., where he repeated false and grossly exaggerated claims about undocumented immigrants that local Republican officials have refuted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: Resilience Has Taken Her From ‘The Hills’ to Brooklyn Heights
description: Glossier founder Emily Weiss attributes her success to never giving up. Plus, jewelry shopping from coast to coast and Wet Seal’s gilded age.
content: Speaking on the phone as she was driving through Manhattan, Emily Weiss turned the conversation to cocktails while discussing the fragrance offerings from Glossier, the beauty brand she founded 10 years ago this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The School for First Ladies Is Now in Session
description: It’s a highly visible role that usually comes with no job description or salary. This group aims to assist. (And yes, first gentlemen are welcome.)
content: On Tuesday, Sept. 24, just after noon, 15 first ladies from around the world gathered for a working lunch focused on public health in a top-floor conference room in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Executives and Research Disagree About Hybrid Work. Why?
description: Companies like Amazon have required a return to the office five days a week despite findings showing benefits to employers that allow some remote days.
content: Amazon’s C.E.O., Andy Jassy, made waves last month when he demanded that all employees return to the office five days a week. The proclamation seemed to validate similar demands made by executives like JPMorgan Chase’s Jamie Dimon and Goldman Sachs’s David Solomon. And it naturally raised the question of whether others might follow suit. (It appears some have.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: A Frustrated Trump Lashes Out Behind Closed Doors Over Money
description: Donald J. Trump is feeling aggrieved, unappreciated by donors and fenced in by security concerns in the final stretch of the race.
content: Donald J. Trump took his seat at the dining table in his triplex penthouse apartment atop Trump Tower on the last Sunday in September, alongside some of the most sought-after and wealthiest figures in the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: How Taryn Delanie Smith, TikTok’s Heaven Receptionist, Spends Sundays
description: Taryn Delanie Smith, a former Miss New York, takes a long stroll with her husband and Great Dane and cues up her Sunday playlist with an Ina Garten-inspired dinner.
content: Before Taryn Delanie Smith was crowned Miss New York in 2022, she worked at a call center. At one point, she said, she was only pretending to take calls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: How Roger Goodell Became the N.F.L.’s $20 Billion Man
description: Under the expansionist leadership of its commissioner, the National Football League is growing richer and richer. So, too, is Mr. Goodell.
content: As they met in the lobby of the Omni Viking Lakes Hotel in Minnesota in late August, Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, and Robert Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, greeted each other warmly, sharing fist bumps as a small entourage that included their oldest sons surrounded them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín and Luis Antonio Rojas
title: These Americans Are Going Back to Mexico as Its Citizens
description: More than 25 years after Mexico began recognizing dual nationals, some U.S.-born children of Mexican immigrants are claiming citizenship in the country that their parents once left.
content: She hid with her four boys under the cover of darkness, the distant shouts of Border Patrol agents and a helicopter droning over the hills on the Tijuana-San Diego border. The agents threatened to end a one-way trip from Mexico to the United States with arrest and deportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Micheline Maynard
title: In Detroit, Creating a New Hub for Innovation
description: Entrepreneurs once flocked to Motor City to build cars. Now, they’re building its mobility future.
content: David Medina Álvarez hopped on a four-wheeled vehicle that looked like a speeder bike from Star Wars. Donning a helmet and goggles, the 25-year-old designer zoomed down 15th Street, driving alongside the massive Michigan Central train station, built in 1913, which had just reopened after a gleaming $1 billion renovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Rise of the Dragons: Fire-Breathing Drones Duel in Ukraine
description: Drones are getting another new twist: Soldiers attach canisters to them to create weapons capable of spitting out molten metal that burns at 4,400 degrees.
content: It was a familiar and vexing problem: Russian soldiers were using the dense cover of tree lines to prepare to storm the Ukrainian trenches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘Are We Not Humans?’
description: My attempt at explaining the murder, rape and famine in Sudan.
content: After my reporting trip to the Chad-Sudan border and columns about the murder, rape and starvation that have devastated Sudan, readers wrote in with many thoughtful comments and questions. Here’s my effort to address some of them:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: Christian Conservatives, Looking to Mobilize Women, Turn to a Biblical Queen
description: Alarmed by abortion and transgender rights, Christian activists are invoking the Old Testament story of Esther, the Jewish orphan who bravely saved her people.
content: The biblical story of Esther, the Jewish orphan who became queen and bravely saved her people, has been a potent symbol for women and girls, a call to lead a life of courage, sacrifice and purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: JD Vance’s Election Denialism Is Deepening
description: Fool me once? Shame on you. Fool me five times?
content: The first thing I thought of while watching Senator JD Vance of Ohio refuse to say whether Donald Trump lost the 2020 presidential election in a recent interview with this newspaper was “The Manchurian Candidate,” John Frankenheimer’s 1962 psychological thriller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s Former First Minister, Dies at 69
description: He led the Scottish National Party twice, guiding it from a fringe political group into a powerful electoral force in Britain.
content: Alex Salmond, the former first minister of Scotland who campaigned for the country to leave the United Kingdom and led the nation during an independence referendum, died on Saturday after delivering a speech in North Macedonia. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Bianca Pallaro
title: Mayor Adams’s Rivals Reveal Fund-Raising Totals. Mr. Adams? Who Knows.
description: With Mayor Eric Adams’s future in flux as he faces federal bribery charges, his challengers prepare for the possibility of an election before the June primary.
content: With Mayor Eric Adams facing a five-count federal indictment and at least four Democratic primary challengers next year, the quarterly fund-raising reporting deadline on Friday carried heightened intrigue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: City Hall Is in Crisis. Who’s Running New York?
description: Mayor Eric Adams is relying on a group of respected civil servants to run the city and a trio of advisers to salvage his political career. Some say it’s too late.
content: For Mayor Eric Adams, the challenge of leading New York City has taken on an almost absurd quality, with his administration peppered in recent weeks by a half-dozen significant resignations, four federal investigations and two federal indictments, including one against the mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Kerasote
title: Quiet as Old as the Beginning of Time
description: Much of what’s still undeveloped offers some the best defenses against climate change.
content: A small, heart-shaped body of water aptly named Green Lake lies at just under 9,000 feet on the western side of the Tetons, deep within the Jedediah Smith Wilderness area of Wyoming. Mirroring the surrounding conifers, the surface of the lake rests perfectly still this fall evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King, Jonathan Weisman and Ruth Igielnik
title: Black Voters Drift From Democrats, Imperiling Harris’s Bid, Poll Shows
description: Vice President Kamala Harris is on track to win a majority of Black voters, and has brought many back to her party since taking over for President Biden. Still, a significant gap in support persists.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has improved her party’s standing among Black voters since President Biden left the presidential race, but she still significantly trails Mr. Biden’s 2020 share of that vital Democratic constituency, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll of Black likely voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger, Tiffany Hsu and Aaron Krolik
title: Twitter Barred Them. What Happened When Elon Musk Brought Them Back?
description: Many users who were reinstated by X have continued to share the kinds of false narratives and conspiracies that once got them suspended.
content: After Hurricane Helene, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the hard-right conservative from Georgia, shared on X the widely debunked claim that government scientists could control the weather. “It’s ridiculous for anyone to lie and say it can’t be done,” she wrote in one post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Led by Believers in the City’s Future, Detroit Is on the Rebound
description: Once the largest city in the U.S. to declare bankruptcy, this Midwestern metropolis is now thriving. But some obstacles still remain.
content: On a sunny Friday morning last month, Mike Duggan, the mayor of Detroit, got behind the wheel of his black Jeep Grand Cherokee to give a tour of the city he has led for 10 years. Not far from Michigan Central Station, the former hulking ruin that was recently transformed into a gleaming office complex, he slowed to point to a construction site of vertical steel girders and yellow earth-moving machines. It will become a 600-room JW Marriott hotel, linked to the city’s convention center and scheduled to open by 2027, when college basketball’s Final Four will be played in Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Boot Found at Everest Could Be From Climber Who Vanished 100 Years Ago
description: When Sandy Irvine went on a pioneering expedition to Mount Everest’s summit in 1924, he and his partner vanished. The recent discovery may shed light on the ill-fated adventure.
content: A well-preserved boot found by a group of climbers on Mount Everest could be a clue to solving one of the most enduring adventure mysteries in the history of exploration of the world’s highest peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Willms
title: One of the World’s Most Immigrant-Friendly Countries Is Changing Course
description: Canada has long had one of the world’s most open immigration policies. Now, faced with a growing popular backlash, it’s changing the rules.
content: A late-night Uber ride from Toronto’s Pearson Airport into the city usually guarantees a good fare for the driver.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Letters in Song Lyrics and Poetry
description: These are some of our favorites from among more than 800 submissions in response to our request for variations on traditional letters.
content: Elections of Yore
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: On the Trail, Vance Is Dogged by Questions About Trump’s Loss in 2020
description: Speaking at a factory for military vehicles in Johnstown, Pa., Senator JD Vance of Ohio again refused to acknowledge former President Donald J. Trump’s defeat in the 2020 election.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, who has faced renewed questions about the 2020 election since refusing at the vice-presidential debate this month to acknowledge that former President Donald J. Trump lost, falsely suggested on Saturday that the election had been “rigged.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ta-Nehisi Coates
description: The Oct. 11, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ta-Nehisi Coates. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: This Election Will Need More Heroes
description: Honorable public servants of both parties upheld democracy after the 2020 election. America is counting on them again to do their duty.
content: True political courage — the principled stand, the elevation of country over party pressure, the willingness to sacrifice a career to protect the common good — has become painfully rare in a polarized world. It deserves to be celebrated and nurtured whenever it appears, especially in defense of fundamental American institutions like our election system. The sad truth, too, is the country will probably need a lot more of it in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Political Uncertainty and Budget Reality Put France in a Financial Vise
description: A rating agency’s warning about the country’s ballooning debt comes as the prime minister tries to push an austerity budget through a divided Parliament.
content: France has become one of the most financially troubled countries in Europe, with an outsize debt and deficit that are likely to keep ballooning despite efforts by a fragile new government to address the problem, the Fitch Ratings agency said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Declares Disaster From Milton Ahead of Florida Visit
description: The president will visit communities ravaged by Hurricane Milton on Sunday. The disaster declaration will enable funds for the state to be deployed.
content: President Biden approved a major disaster declaration for Florida for communities ravaged by Hurricane Milton, freeing up federal funding to assist in the state’s recovery and rebuilding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Lee Minho Needs His Notes App
description: “Whenever I get inspiration or feel something,” the “Pachinko” star said, “I go to my Notes app and write it down.”
content: Four years ago, the actor and singer Lee Minho was yearning for a shift in his career. It was around this time that he received the script for Season 1 of “Pachinko,” the drama that follows four generations of a Korean immigrant family, based on the novel by Min Jin Lee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: This Is Why Trump Imagines He Will Win
description: The way he is now running is the best window we have into what kind of president he will be in a second term.
content: If Donald Trump wins, the people who voted for him would have a range of reasons for putting him in office. There are a lot of potential Trump voters who don’t like him that much or who really like only parts of his personality or platform and tolerate the rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Tester’s Fight for Political Survival Is Democrats’ Last Stand on the Great Plains
description: Once able to win on the prairie, the Democratic Party sees the Senate race in Montana as a final test of whether it can still be successful in heavily rural states that have turned deep red.
content: When Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat and political fixture in Montana, was re-elected to a sixth term in 2008, all of the statewide offices down the ballot — governor, attorney general, secretary of state, state auditor and school superintendent — were won by fellow Democrats. A sole Republican took the state’s single seat in the House of Representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson Makes a Case for Trump’s Return, and Perhaps, His Own
description: In his memoir, “Unleashed,” the former prime minister is “optimistic” about the possibility that Donald J. Trump could regain the White House.
content: Boris Johnson knows he’s often cast as Donald J. Trump’s populist twin, and he puts up a perfunctory protest. Analogies between Brexit, which he championed, and Trump’s MAGA movement are “pretty treacherous,” he said, and the caricature of himself as a louche, shambling, Eton-and-Oxford version of Trump does no favors to the once-and-maybe-future American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Who Are These People Interviewing Trump and Harris?
description: For the presidential candidates, the media future is now.
content: In 2015, Barack Obama submitted to interviews with three YouTube stars, one of whom was notable for eating cereal out of a bathtub. It was a moment that opened a window into the media landscape of the future, after the mainstream media as we have known it — while also making that future seem basically absurd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: What International Law Says About Israel’s Invasion of Lebanon
description: Explaining the issues of sovereignty, self-defense and humanitarian safeguards.
content: Since the start of Israel’s invasion of Lebanon last month, debate has swirled regarding the wisdom of Israel’s two-front strategy amid the ongoing conflict in Gaza, the threat that the fight against Hezbollah poses to civilians and the risk it could ignite a regional war with Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Hurricanes Amplify Insurance Crisis in Riskiest Areas
description: After Helene and Milton, some small Florida companies risk bankruptcy. Larger ones will be in the hot seat with lawmakers and consumer groups.
content: Until late last month, there was optimism in the insurance industry. Hurricane season had been quiet and the number of wildfires was still below the yearly average. Insurers were beginning to hope that the cost of reinsurance — that is, insurance for insurers — would only inch up next year, instead of shooting higher as it did the previous two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: A Mystery Repeats: Harris Up 4 in Pennsylvania, and Trump Up 6 in Arizona
description: Being uncertain about our earlier poll results but finding almost the same numbers the next time around.
content: At the end of our last wave of post-debate battleground polls, there were two state poll results that didn’t seem to fit the rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: Dreamtroit, a Low-Cost Bohemia for Artists, Revs Up in Motor City
description: The former Lincoln Motor factory is in the vanguard of new development poised to transform moribund automotive facilities into affordable housing and art studios.
content: Maurice Cox, the former planning director of the city of Detroit, remembers the first time Matthew Naimi wandered into his office in paint-splattered overalls in 2018, with fingernail polish, a kaffiyeh on his head, and his bare arms a constellation of tattoos. When Naimi told him that he wanted to develop a multimillion-dollar low-cost housing complex for artists out of one of the city’s most dilapidated automobile factories, long abandoned, “it was bordering on satire,” Cox recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Why I Changed My Birth Certificate 25 Years After I Transitioned
description: I’m taking steps to secure my future in an uncertain time for trans people in America.
content: My wife was the one who told me that the birth certificate for Baby Girl Boylan had finally arrived in the mail in late summer. It had been a long time coming — 66 years, in fact — because Baby Girl Boylan, of course, was me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Harris Says She Would Form Bipartisan Council of Advisers
description: The stop in Arizona was part of the Harris campaign’s strategy to court Republicans disaffected with former President Donald J. Trump.
content: As Vice President Kamala Harris has sought to stake out ground in the political center that might appeal to swing voters, she has campaigned with former Representative Liz Cheney, the Wyoming Republican, and pledged to appoint a Republican to her cabinet if elected. Ms. Harris added to that strategy while visiting the battleground state of Arizona on Friday, saying she would convene a bipartisan council of advisers on policy if she wins the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon and Patrick Kingsley
title: Secret Documents Show Hamas Tried to Persuade Iran to Join Its Oct. 7 Attack
description: The Times reviewed the minutes of 10 meetings among Hamas’s top leaders. The records show the militant group avoided several escalations since 2021 to falsely imply it had been deterred — while seeking Iranian support for a major attack.
content: For more than two years, Yahya Sinwar huddled with his top Hamas commanders and plotted what they hoped would be the most devastating and destabilizing attack on Israel in the militant group’s four-decade history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: A Tender Ode to a 1960s ‘Women’s Hotel’
description: Daniel M. Lavery’s debut novel collects vignettes from inside the Biedermeier, a second-rate, rapidly waning establishment in midcentury New York City.
content: It’s the 1960s, and New York’s venerable Biedermeier hotel, a second-rate but genteel women’s residence, is, like the city around it, changing. Few patrons require the chaperones or house rules such institutions offer. Breakfast service has been suspended; rooms lie empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Where Is the Fierce Urgency of Beating Trump?
description: The vice president needs to pull out all the stops to get out of her stall.
content: Barack Obama got blunt in Pittsburgh on Thursday. He chided Black men who are not supporting Kamala Harris, saying that some of “the brothers” were just not “feeling the idea of having a woman as president.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: 5 Takeaways From Vance’s Interview With The New York Times
description: Pressed to say if he thought the 2020 election was stolen, JD Vance repeatedly sidestepped. And he defended the sentiment behind his “childless cat ladies” comment, even as he regretted his word choice.
content: JD Vance keeps showing up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: David Garrard Lowe, Defender of Historic Architecture, Dies at 91
description: For over 50 years, as a historian, lecturer and author, he fought to protect Beaux-Arts buildings in New York and Chicago from falling to the developer’s wrecking ball.
content: David Garrard Lowe, a writer and architectural historian whose passion for historic preservation — and in particular for the Beaux-Arts mansions, museums and towers of the Gilded Age — helped stem the tide of urban renewal that was leveling large swaths of American cities in the decades after World War II, died on Sept. 21 in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The OB-GYN Running on Abortion Rights in Conservative Wisconsin
description: Dr. Kristin Lyerly is looking to make inroads in a heavily Catholic part of the state.
content: It was 7:15 a.m. on Sunday, and a blood-orange sun had turned the sky lavender. Dr. Kristin Lyerly was getting ready to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers, Reid J. Epstein and Gina Kolata
title: Daring Trump, Harris’s Campaign Releases Medical Information
description: Vice President Kamala Harris released a letter from her doctor saying that she is in “excellent health,” as her campaign tries to capitalize on the lack of health information shared by her rival.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris released a letter on Saturday from her White House doctor, who said she is in “excellent health” and is successfully managing some minor health issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: The Cutting-Edge Hearing Aids That You May Already Own
description: Apple is preparing to turn its AirPods Pro 2 into easy-to-use aids for people with mild to moderate hearing loss.
content: In your pocket or purse, you may be toting around small devices that, with the help of new software authorized by the Food and Drug Administration, could soon become inexpensive hearing aids. Millions of people already own them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,212
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: California Tries ‘Trump-Proofing’ Its Climate Policies
description: A second Trump administration would be expected to shred climate polices. California officials are devising ways to insulate its environmental regulations.
content: California officials have been working for months on a plan to “Trump proof” the state’s leading edge environmental and climate policies, in the event that former President Donald J. Trump returns to White House and follows through on his promise to gut them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: China’s ‘New Great Wall’ Casts a Shadow on Nepal
description: Nepalis have complained that China’s breaches of the border threaten their land and their way of life.
content: Nepalis have complained that China’s breaches of the border threaten their land and their way of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Alice Fang
title: How Eric Adams Could Leave Office, and Who Hopes to Succeed Him
description: Mr. Adams’s political future is in doubt after federal prosecutors indicted him on corruption charges in one of several inquiries ensnaring City Hall.
content: Mr. Adams’s political future is in doubt after federal prosecutors indicted him on corruption charges in one of several inquiries ensnaring City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Interview’: A Conversation With JD Vance
description: In this interview, Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, rejects the idea that he has changed, defends his rhetoric and still won’t say whether former President Donald J. Trump lost in 2020.
content: In this interview, Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, rejects the idea that he has changed, defends his rhetoric and still won’t say whether former President Donald J. Trump lost in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: JD Vance: Not Having Kids Due to Climate Change Is ‘Crazy’
description: Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-president nominee, said that considering climate change when deciding to have kids was a “bizarre way to think about the future.”
content: Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-president nominee, said that considering climate change when deciding to have kids was a “bizarre way to think about the future.”
source.name: The New York Times
